title: Day or night? (v2)
description:
A more minimalist project, remixed from an old project. I was a little pressed for time, but it was also a good reminder that these challenges are intended to be quick and easy, even if it's also so easy to get sucked into the work! 

It's also funny to go back to old projects and see how your style was different. For some reason, in the old one, my noise-dependency if it was loud was a forever loop triggered by the sound, whereas if it was soft, it was an if statement inside a forever loop. There are only two options though - why not wrap them both in the same forever loop? *headshake*
instructions: Just press the green flag!

title: Steven's Song!
description: This was so fun! I used this challenge as an opportunity to also play with the sound recordings which I hadn't used before! I wanted to make Steven come to life.
instructions: Press the flag to start, and then click on Steven to get your instructions!

title: Chromophobia
description: For Day 15 of Getting Unstuck, I imagined what Josef Albers (the great Bauhaus artist) might make with Scratch. (I'm currently reading Albers' "Interaction of Color".) As part of my research for this project, I came across an Atlantic article (https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2014/12/the-secrets-of-color/382229/) about Albers. The article mentions a historical confusion, anxiety, and fear around color, described as "chromophobia". I thought this was a fascinating word (and cultural phenomenon); hence, the title.
instructions:
Press the green flag to start.
Make sure that your computer audio is audible.
Use the slider to adjust the instrument.
Use your computer's controls to adjust volume up and down.
Watch how the square pulses vary according to instrument and volume.

title: Amplitude
description:
This project was created for Day 15 of Getting Unstuck. While I was playing with an idea for a different sound-based project, I kept wondering what the "loudness" block was really capturing. I created a variable to display the loudness, so I could see its value. But the value was changing very quickly, and it was hard to get a sense of the individual numbers. 

So I created this project to visualize what was happening. I liked it enough that I set aside the other project idea and focused on this helpful tool instead.
instructions: Click the green flag and make some noise. Use the time scale control to magnify.

title: Star Songs
description:
As I thought about what to create for sound detection, I wanted to see how I could have clones of something represent the shifts in sound visually. I decided to give myself a very short time limit to create a simple sprite in the vector editor (to continue exploring the drawing to programming time ratio in creating my projects). I ended up creating this star which led me to think of a twinkling night sky.

Initially I had intended to have more sensing ranges. As I would run my program, unexpected movements were happening, and the changes I was hoping for were not. I decided to simplify and just have two possibilities, above or below 30. At this point, I was able to get the visual effects I wanted (which included trying what I thought I wanted and deciding I *didn't* want that a few times) The program was running, though, so that was great! 

Boiling effects down to their most simplified and then building on that is a strategy I could probably benefit from using more. My mind often goes real big rather than starting small, and I think that I'd like to try building big and wide from simple, more easily trackable (and therefore tinkerable!), steps.
instructions:
Press then green flag, and then sing (or scream, whatever you need,) to the stars! I recommend full screen (:

(you'll need to be sure your microphone is on and that scratch is allowed to use it)

(sometimes I need to refresh the page before scratch will ask for mic permission -- bug? anyone else have this issue?)

title: Getting Unstuck Day 15: Library Adventure
description:
Images from Pixabay.com
Thanks to Jhenna for playing an angry child.

I originally had trouble thinking of an idea for today's challenge. Eventually, I went with a simple idea (that deviated slightly from the prompt): a library where someone yells at you if you speak too loudly. This, of course, led to some Hogwarts-themed ideas! I tried to mimic what happens in Hogwarts if you open up a book from the restricted section...

If I had more time, I think I'd add more tempting items that shriek when opened :)
instructions:
WELCOME TO THE HOGWARTS LIBRARY!

Click on the green flag to be given instructions. Stay quiet long enough and you may be tempted by books in the restricted section!

(turn your sound on and up!)

title: Day15
instructions:
Click on the green flag to start.
Press arrows up and down to control volume

description:
GettingUnstuck 15: This project combines ideas from the previous two unstuck projects, in which I've been reiterating on a way of drawing on the trackpad. In this iteration, alternate between different geometric shapes using loudness. Play the arrow keys and space bar. Shapes also rotate at different speeds depending on loudness. This week, I only have a few minutes for my own Scratch projects each morning, so I'm curating the same few ideas over several days. One thing that I wish I could explore further is using advanced algorithms to make the music (note and instrument selection, sound bending, etc) and other functions smoother.

From Unstuck 14, two exciting discoveries were (1) using mouse x and mouse y to change notes, and (2) using a pointer finger on the track pad to draw without ever clicking. I want to push further with these ideas.

There is additional graphics code that had to be disassembled because they were causing the program to freeze.
instructions:
Green flag, draw with fingertip on track pad.

Designed for makeymakey with grounded ring, connect to right left up down and space (see photos within). Change notes by changing mouse-x, change instruments (3 instruments available) by changing mouse-y.

Try left, up, right, space, down.

title: Day 15 Angry Teacher
description:
Today I needed to compelte a project in a short space of time.  Ive been spending way too long.
My challenge was to create something that I could use again in my classroom.
The noise levels for sound might not be set too accuratley, but if you start in a relatively quiet room and sing 'LAAA' progressively getting louder, the sprite should change what she says in response.  The end comment for a noisy room was just a fun element I decided to add.  I might work on this a bit later and add more sounds and more elements to it. 

Enjoy.
As always, I welcome feedback.

Oh and my wow moment today was ACTUALLY getting multiple conditionals to work for me!!!!! Yippee!!!

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 15 ‚Äî Sound Level
description:
Reflection

I started out doing exactly what the project of the day was. This part of it came together fairly quickly. At this point I took a moment to figure out what else I can do to create a slightly more polished product.

First, I realized I wasn't in a great environment for testing this, but I wanted it to work reliably. This led to me creating a Sensitivity slider so the project could be calibrated.

Second, I wanted the sound level to gradually decay over time.
instructions: This sketch changes backgrounds based on how loud the room is. Use the sensitivity slide to calibrate the project.

title: Noise = Scratch Stamps! (Getting Unstuck #15)
description:
Getting Unstuck #15 - "Create a project that shows different backgrounds depending on how loud the room is."

I had no idea Scratch could interact with a laptop's microphone! This is fairly basic as I had limited time but it's a fun interaction.  

Potential improvements:
- don't stamp if loudness 0.
- stamp slightly more frequently (tried to do this but it stopped stamping for some reason)
- use random polygons as stamp rather than Scratch costume.
instructions:
- Click the flag to start (restart or reload page if microphone not working)
- Be noisy and see what patterns you can make (stamps every half second). I find blowing into your microphone works great.

I mostly got stuck with the microphone permissions on my laptop, but also with timing all these events, and used the Wiki and the 'help' option in the Scratch editor to re-learn how to use the 'broadcast () and wait' block.

title: workshop tool - noise level
description:
Getting Unstuck: Day 15
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu/
Create a project that shows different backgrounds depending on how loud the room is. 

ToDo/Remix idea: add a loudness graph

Thanks to PixLoger for the CC0 smileys!
https://pixabay.com/en/photos/?q=user%3APixLoger+smiley
instructions:
A noise meter that can be displayed during a scratch workshop, so that the kids can easily see when the room is too noisy.
(Apparently, some teachers are using an electronic version of this in class, shaped like a traffic light)

Press the green flag, allow access to the microphone access, and then make some noise :)
Use the space key to display the settings:
- sensitivity adjusts the noise thresholds, lower sensitivity means that more noise is needed to make the yellow/red smileys appear.
- persistence is how long the yellow/red smileys stay after the noise has gone down again.

title: What's That Racket? GU_Day15
description:
Today, I began by reading articles about decibels. I am playing with testing my voice. When my loudness variable is = 0.1 and I whisper, that level of loudness is not be sensed until my distance from the screen is only a few inches. I want to know if sounds that are played in Scratch can be detected. I am testing "meow". Yes, but, the results for calibration are not consistent. I settle on a rather straight-forward project that allows the user to experiment with the controls. 
Credits:
https://www.thecut.com/2016/05/what-it-s-like-to-be-unable-to-bear-the-sound-of-someone-eating.html
instructions:
Click on the green flag. Then adjust the slider controls when they appear. You may use the sounds that the sprites make, or sounds in your environment to explore!

***Oops, I just realized that in my wonderings and explorations, I missed the part of today's challenge about signaling background changes.

title: Day 15-Loudness Test Pattern
description:
Day 15-Create a project that shows different backgrounds depending on how loud the room is. 

This was my first time using the loudness input and I love it! Just created a simple test pattern that changes color, but kids would have so much fun thinking of silly ways to use this.

The block of color automatically gets smaller if it's quiet, but changes size according to the loudness. I multiplied the loudness to make the size change more quickly.

Watch the pattern change and block change according to the level of noise.

title: Monkey Alphabet 1
description:
bensound for background music
scratch for sprites and sound effects
voice overs by csn4710 (aka wife)

Let me tell you, watching the kids work together, even as three year olds (not year 3, but actually 3 years old), was amazing. We actually used it in as a physical activity because we noticed along with yelling the letter, they kids were also jumping.  

I did try motion controls but it was far to inaccurate. I have a few ideas but will have to see them through first.
instructions:
I created this for my 3year old, pre school and kindergarten classes. I would have them stand up and then yell as a team, teamwork is essential for this game, to help him collect the letter they lost from their backpack. 

Also added a secondary choice to use the keyboard. 

The intro is a reminder to always zip up your backpack. 

3/31/18
Created for a classroom to be projected. Works on based on sound level. Kids can yell out the letter to make the monkey jump.

ALso can press J key for individual play. Press space to use the sound slider to make the response higher or lower depending on classroom acoustics 

4/1/18
Added Keyboard controls. Press 1 for standard, 2 for keyboard
Randomized letters

title: Happy Birthday
description:
Reflection:  I didn't have a chance all day to get to this project and by the time I did, I only remembered that I had to use the loudness sensing block. So, the background is not affected by loudness.

If I had more time, I would have the background change depending on loudness, too.  I was figuring out ways to do that by tinkering with the ballerinas' costume changes to increase with loudness.

My spouse suggested a cumulative loudness be reached instead of an instantaneous level. (So you actually have to sing the whole song).
instructions:
Getting Unstuck #15: Create a project that shows different backgrounds depending on how loud the room is.

Well, I took creative license with the directions.  Click the green flag and Heart will take it from there.

title: Day 15 - Sound in space
description: Day 15 - Create a project that shows different backgrounds depending on how¬†loud¬†the room is.
instructions: Click on the flag.

title: The next door
description:
My first idea for today was: a game where you can control the character with the microphone. I realized that it could be a bit challenging, so I decided to chose another one.
Eventually, I had a simple idea: a game where you can change the stage with your voice at a specific time. 
I've also added some elements to make it difficult and fun.
When you find the hidden door you will always change your size automatically.

                                     ---My next goal---
If I had more tome I'd like to add more obstacles, levels and use the loudness in another way.

                                     ----Credits----
+ Sprites and backgrounds: All of them have been created with the Scratch paint editor.
instructions:
WELCOME TO "THE NEXT DOOR".
Move your character to find the hidden door and get pieces of your spaceship. The door helps you to change your size. When you are on the edge, don't forget to speak or blow into the microphone in order to go to a different room.
*Warning*: when you touch a wall or obstacle you will go to the initial position.
*Tips*: try to have the ideal size to avoid the obstacles.

                                             ---Controls---
Press the green flag and then the play button.
Use the arrow keys to move your character.
Press space bar to show your item list.

                        ---Getting Unstuck Day 15---
"Create a project that shows different backgrounds depending on how loud the room is."

title: All we need is ‚ô• (for Scratch)
description:
I'm sooo excited about this project!

The Scratch Conference will start in a few days and I wanted to celebrate my love for Scratch and share it with the awesome community of people around Scratch.

Making this project took me hours, and during the process I got stuck, unstuck, stuck again, changed my mind plentiful of times, introduced bugs, discovered bugs, introduced more bugs, added, deleted, undeleted, edited scripts, costumes, ideas, and listened to this song hundreds of times!

It's one way to express my deepest and lifelong gratitude to:

- @mres, @natalie, and the @Scratchteam for creating Scratch
- @karenb and the @ScratchEdTeam for getting me unstuck
- the Beatles for composing this song
- @yknups for the sprites I remixed in this project
- the entire Scratch community for their love

with ‚ô•, 
@tarmelop
instructions: Click the green flag and sing along

title: Stormy weather
description:
This project responds to the #GettingUnstuck Day 15 challenge:  "Create a project that shows different backgrounds depending on how loud the room is."

I've been playing with the loudness settings to test sensitivity.  It would be fun to include other types of inclement weather and even nature noises (that users would need to replicate, of course!).

Rainy Street photo from chrismetcalfTV https://www.flickr.com/photos/laffy4k/155406169
Lightning audio by Mike Koenig http://soundbible.com/2016-Thunder-Strike-2.html

Day #15 Challenge: Create a project that shows different backgrounds depending on how loud the room is.

Day 20 is Day 15 project remixed  - oops NOT remixed.  I jforgot - 
If I just make changes to the project instead of remixing it the first project is GONE!!!!! 
It is gone from My Stuff and it is gone from the original Day 15 Unstuck Studio.
I wanted to make a project that had a series of unrelated actions so that a player needed to figure out what was happening in this project.
Sorry it is so late today.  I arrived in Boston this morning and had to decide whether to do the Unstuck homework or ... play hookey and see the sites.  The tourist in me won out!!! Visited JFK Museum.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 15
description:
My inspiration....doing this project while watching The Open on TV.

Instead of changing backgrounds I chose to use the loudness to affect story flow.

I would like to add sound effects, like golf swing and ball strike.  Any free sound library suggestions would be appreciated.

My most difficult part...getting the timing.  Still believe that instead of using wait blocks it's easiest to broadcast between sprites to insure timing.
instructions:

You only need to click the green flag.  It makes it's own noise, but feel free to cheer as well.  Tiger Woods cannot hit is shot until he has silence for 5 seconds.

title: Getting Unstuck Day 15
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 15 Reflection:
This might be my favorite project so far!  I think I need to tweak the numbers a bit, but I didn't want to get too loud when people are sleeping.  :)
I've seen teachers use a noise-meter before, usually an app or a part of Smart Notebook.  I wanted to see if I could create one.  I looked for public domain stoplight images I could modify.  The one I chose can be found here: http://moziru.com/explore/Traffic%20Light%20clipart%20black%20and%20white/#go_post_10344_street-light-clipart-street-stop-2.png
instructions: Click on the green flag to keep track of the noise level.

title: Unstuck 15 - Sound Change
description: Back to the idea of a combination of randomness and input to create artwork. I wonder if I replaced the randomness with some order - like writing top to bottom, left to right - if you could see patterns in music or speech. I wish there was a way to detect pitch and other qualities of sound to have more inputs for patterns - to change shape, etc...

title: Getting Unstuck Day 15
description:
I LOVE this kind of project that uses loudness sensing. They were always so popular when I was a teacher.
This one has been made for #GettingUnstuck Day 15 #CreativeComputing.
I remember years ago trying to make a loudness monitor for the classroom which would give the kids visual feedback when they got too loud in class. I never really got it working back then. This 
seems to work a little better.
I'd like to make one with a bar that grows larger as loudness goes up.

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 15
description:
The challenge for day 15 of Getting Unstuck is: "Create a project that shows different backgrounds depending on how loud the room is."

I set up three different backgrounds and they would constantly flicker, so I did some research and discovered that the loudness goes to 100 (and not 10).   :-) 

Backdrop Images for Pixabay:
https://pixabay.com/en/audience-backlit-band-battle-1868137/
https://pixabay.com/en/concert-performance-audience-336695/
